file_content.text: Belsavis owes you a debt it can never repay.
Colonel Bartaph, I was told you wanted to see me.
First, let me express my gratitude. Your actions saved many Republic soldiers.
I'm always glad to help the Republic Army.
It was my honor.
Some of my superiors don't trust your Order. They'll have to revise their opinions after this.
Your special forces were invaluable during the battle with Executor Krannus.
And they returned the favor.
I'll make sure their actions are properly recognized. It isn't every day soldiers are praised by a Jedi.
I won't waste your time, but there's something I need you to clear up for me.
The Empire's forces were all over Belsavis when I arrived. Someone had to stop them, and your people weren't up to it.
They couldn't save themselves.
Your lack of humility aside, my people only just got here. We're doing fine, thank you.
I'll make the rest of this quick. There's some confusion I need you to clear up.
My forces apprehended this man during the riots. He was with a prisoner gang that attacked some guards.
I told you. I was shooting at the gang, not the guards! I'm on your side.
According to his comm logs, you spoke several times. Why were you communicating with one of the galaxy's worst criminals?
His information helped me hunt down Executor Krannus.
He assisted my mission.
That corroborates half of his story. The rest of it is still a problem.
He said he could help find Executor Krannus, but all I received was some useless data.
[Lie] We hardly spoke.
That's a lie! I helped you find Doctor Gantrell's team! They'll back me up!
Pak is looking for a way off Belsavis. He thought helping me was his ticket out.
I think he was using me.
I never asked you for anything!
I risked my life for you, and you turned around and stole those weapon prototypes!
The ones Doctor Gantrell's team was developing? You took them?
The Jedi are at war and I'll take every advantage I can get.
I need to stop the Empire.
I understand. Would've been nice if you'd asked.
I make dozens of life-and-death choices every day. This was one of them.
Don't question my actions.
I'll have to report this to my superiors. If they have a problem with your decision, they'll be in touch.
Frankly, I'm starting to wonder if Pak is telling the truth. I'm inclined to believe him.
Seriously, Colonel, you shouldn't believe everything that comes out of his mouth.
[Lie] He's lying.
You're right. I'll put him in a cell.
No! That's not fair! You couldn't have saved this planet without me!
Despite his lies about the prototypes, he did help me. He's earned some freedom.
Let him go.
I don't know what's going on between you two, but I have bigger problems right now.
I'm not a prisoner anymore. The warden made me an honorary guard. It's true!
There is no evidence to support your statement.
My instinct is to throw Pak into the nearest cell, but there is a chance he's being honest. What do you think?
My forces apprehended this prisoner during the riots. I need to know why one of the galaxy's worst criminals was helping you.
There must be some mistake. Pak is not one of the inmates.
He's a guard, not a prisoner.
I thought Pak was one of the guards. You're telling me he's one of the inmates?
What are you talking about?
I could sense you were hiding something.
I knew you were a liar, Pak.
It's true. I came here a decade ago as a prisoner, and I deserved it. I did things you don't want to know about.
Being on Belsavis--surrounded by scum just like me--it opened my eyes. Even if I could never leave here, I could still change.
It took years, but I did it. The warden made me an honorary guard. Said I earned that.
You worked hard to turn your life around, and he rewarded you for it.
Sounds like you did.
You kept this a secret from me. You're a liar.
I don't believe you.
Once a criminal, always a criminal. Sooner or later, you'll fall back to your old ways.
People don't change.
I'm trying to make up for the terrible things I've done. The warden gave me that chance.
So you claim. Unfortunately, we have no evidence to support your story.
It's possible the records were destroyed in all the chaos. However, it's also possible you're lying.
Whatever he used to be, he's changed. I couldn't have saved Belsavis without him.
Pak is a good man.
What were his crimes? Why is Pak imprisoned for life on Belsavis?
Why was he a prisoner?
Only the most vicious and dangerous criminals end up here. Take the worst crimes you can imagine, and multiply them by a thousand.
I'm not like that anymore. I helped you.
He had every chance to tell me the truth about himself. I think he'd say anything to stay out of a cell.
Don't believe him, Colonel.
I can help you. I've changed.
Now you see my dilemma. I don't want to imprison someone who doesn't deserve it, but I don't want to set a criminal free.
I couldn't have completed my mission without Pak. He's earned his freedom.
Let him go.
I'm not authorized to let Pak leave Belsavis, but I can see that he is restored to his guard status.
This means everything to me. Thank you both.
If the warden made Pak a guard, someone knows about it. Keep him in the holding cell until you find the truth.
Wait until you find proof.
That sounds reasonable. Pak, you'll stay here until we get this all straightened out.
Guess it's better than going back into genpop....
Criminals don't get special treatment. Lock him up with the rest of the inmates.
Throw him back in the prison.
No! Do you know what the other prisoners will do to me? You're a disgrace to the Jedi!
Enough! Remove the prisoner at once!
I'm sure you have business elsewhere. Thank you again for everything you did here.
I'm trying to bring some order to Belsavis. You'll have to wait.
